div1.p: Lazear describes life in Edinburgh and the surrounding countryside.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, June 8, 1890
div1.opener:
1
18 Chalmers St. Edinburgh
June 8, 1890
My dear Mother,-
div1.p:
This afternoon, we
made a journey to the top of Arthur's Seat.
It is really quite a climb and is
much farther from town than I had
supposed. It was raining as usual
so the view was limited but it
was still very beautifull.
Edinburgh lies just to the west and
to the north lies the Firth of Forth stretching
eastward to the North Sea. In all
other directions you see a landscape
of hills and valleys. Between Arthur's
Seat and the city there is another
high hill called Salisburg Craig.
Just at the foot and near Holyrood
there is Saint Anthony's chapel and well
neither of which amounts to much.
Holyrood Palace itself is a disap-
pointment in its outside view (I have
not yet seen the interior). It is a dingy
barracks looking place. To tell the
truth Edinburgh must certainly be called
dingy as a whole. There is always
a cloud of smoke hanging over
and whenever you leave a window
open you find a pile of soot
on the sill. For all that
it is a beautiful town, there
is harmony about the general
architecture that we do not
see in America.

The people here are an odd lot.
They are nearly all devout Presbyterians
They attend church regularly about
five times every Sunday and I
don't know how many times during
the week. They are not given to
swearing, they seem to make a
special point against profanity.
I don't think I have heard an
oath since I got here. All this is
in their favor, but I never saw such
a place for drunkenness in my
life. You see men and women
fall down in the principal streets
at all hours of day or night and
nobody seems to think anything of it.
They get beastly drunk, you don't
see them just mildly I intoxicated
but they all seem just on the
borders of collapse. I took
3
a walk, last night and really
about nine in every ten persons
I met, were drunk.

Last night I went to the Royal Circus
to see Sampson, the strong man. His
performance was very good, but
the rest of the show amounted to
nothing, so we left as soon
as Sampson had finished his
act.

I had hoped to get a letter from
you today as this is one of the American
mail days but none came.

This afternoon Stanley was given
the degree of L.L.D. by the University.
The ceremony look place in the
library which is not large enough
to hold all the students so we
gathered in the quadrangle to
see the party go in. While I
was standing there the curator
of the Museum came up to me
and offered me a ticket of admission
to the hall. He said he had seen
plenty of graduations and did not care
to go in. It was very kind of him.
I notice a disposition on the part of
all the instructors and officers to
be especially kind to us Americans.
Well I went in in and saw the
ceremony which was very simple.
The Big Guns of the University were
on a platform dressed in brilliant
robes, each seemed to have different
colors. One of them got up and
made made a very few remarks and
another placed the cap on Stanley's
head. Then Stanley made an address
which for egotism stands way over
anything I ever heard of. He held
himself up as the great model of the
universe.

Yesterday afternoon as I was
dissecting, Dr Hepburn walked
up and introduced an old white
haired gentleman who turned
out to be the great Sir William
Turner, the professor of Anatomy. He
had just returned from London
where he had been attending
the Medical Council. He talked
very pleasantly for a few minutes
and I really did not feel much
abashed at my first contact
with the nobility. They say he
takes great interest in the students
work and frequently comes into
the dissecting room and walks
5
around the room taking scalpel
& forceps and giving points to the
students. It is a very unusual
thing for a head professor to do
like that, most of them never
enter the dissecting room.

The students here are much more
noisy than American students. When
we were all in the Quadrangle
the instructors etc passed in, those
whom who were popular were loudly
cheers, while the examiners were
all hooted. The hooting was a
new thing to me. The Americans
express displeasure by silence
while the Britons hoots and groans.
The noise they make is very well
expressed by the word h-o-o-t,
At the opera the students all
sit in the gallery and sing
for half-an-hour before the
performance begins and again
between the acts. I have not
yet heard them but they say
they sing excellently.

I bought a copy of the Heart
of Mid-Lothian this afternoon
which I am going to read.
So this book will be published
bought and read in Edinburgh,
and as the story is about
Edinburgh and by a man who
lived in Edinburgh, it will make
a good souvenir of my visit
here. I saw the heart in
the side street crossing, the
other day, which marks the
site of the old Tolbooth,
